subject: Medicine
title: Placebo Ethics
description: A micro-lesson that makes Placebo Ethics usable.

hook.text: To test a new drug, some patients get the real pill and others get a sugar pill. Is it ethical to give someone nothing?

buildup.text: Placebo-controlled trials are the gold standard for proving a treatment works beyond psychological effects.

discovery.text: They're ethical when no proven treatment exists. Patients must know they might receive a placebo.

twist.text: Giving a placebo when effective treatment exists means deliberately withholding helpâ€”a serious ethical violation.

climax.text: The Helsinki Declaration states placebos should only be used when no proven intervention exists.

punchline.text: Testing requires comparison. Ethics demands fairness.

quiz.question: When is it unethical to use a placebo in a clinical trial?
options: When a proven effective treatment already exists
Whenever patients are aware they might receive a placebo
Placebos are always considered unethical in research
